item.title: Bangladesh’s Leader Resigns and Flees Country After Protests
item.description: The country’s army chief said an interim government would be formed, as demonstrators successfully challenged Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina’s harsh rule.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Netanyahu’s Spat With Biden Echoes Dispute With Israel’s Security Chiefs
item.description: Senior Israeli security officials have grown frustrated with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over his perceived resistance to a swift cease-fire deal with Hamas.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Myanmar Rebels Gain Regional Military Base in Lashio, a Major Win
item.description: The seizure of the military’s northeastern command post gives the resistance control of a city and airport on a crucial trade corridor to China.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:description: Soldiers of the Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army patrolling in the Kokang region in 2015.

item.title: Riots Break Out Across UK: What to Know
item.description: The country begins a new week on edge after anti-immigrant riots, fanned by disinformation from the far right, broke out in cities across Britain.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Anti-immigration protesters clashed with police officers in Rotherham, England, on Sunday.

item.title: Japan Needs Foreign Workers. It’s Just Not Sure It Wants Them to Stay.
item.description: Foreign employees have become much more visible in Japan. But policies designed only for short-term stays may hurt the country in the global competition for labor.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Winda Zahra, a worker from Indonesia, with a resident at a care home in Maebashi, the capital of Gunma Prefecture in central Japan.

item.title: Trying to Save a Concrete ‘Monument to Corruption’
item.description: An icon of socialist modernist architecture in the capital of the former Soviet republic that is now Moldova has been at the center of a tussle between corrupt developers and preservationists.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: The former National Hotel in Chisinau, Moldova.

item.title: How Two Russian Spies Went Deep Undercover With Their Children
item.description: A couple planted as sleeper spies in Slovenia posed as an Argentine art dealer and an entrepreneur. They were caught in December 2022 and sent to Moscow in a sweeping prisoner exchange last week.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Manca Juvan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Russian Embassy in Ljubljana, Slovenia. Russia has a long history of investing heavily in so-called illegals, spies who burrow deep into target countries over many years.

item.title: Samsung Employees Return to Work After Strike Fails to Win Concessions
item.description: The indefinite strike, the first in the electronics company’s history, comprised only a sliver of its labor force and lasted less than a month.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Tina Hsu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers protesting outside Samsung’s offices in Seoul in June.

item.title: How Could Maduro’s Reign in Venezuela End?
item.description: After another dubious election victory, Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, appears firmly in power. The only real potential threat, history shows, may come if his own security forces betray him.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro, the authoritarian leader of Venezuela, has been in power since 2013.

item.title: How Did Flavor Flav Become a Hype Man for the U.S. Women’s Water Polo Team?
item.description: The rapper has become a self-appointed hype man and benefactor to the U.S. women’s team in Paris. He plans to keep the poolside party going into 2028.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: “They know deep down in their hearts and they know way in the back of their mind that Flav is right there for us,” America’s newest water polo superfan said.

item.title: How Norway Became a Summer and Winter Olympics Powerhouse
item.description: With money from an oil boom, Norway, a force at the Winter Olympics for generations, is now churning out elite performers in track, soccer and other sports, too.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and David B. Torch
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times

item.title: How Will the Bangladesh Army Respond to Student Protests?
item.description: The military has a history of coups and counter coups. But in this showdown, it has seemed uncomfortable with the police crackdown on protesters.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Shayeza Walid
item.media:description: Bangladeshi soldiers with a cutout of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina last month. Though she has assiduously courted the army’s loyalty, the military has seemed troubled by the recent crackdown.

item.title: Hamas May Emerge Battered, but Not Beaten, From Israel’s Latest Blows
item.description: The assassinations of two Hamas leaders may be a short-term setback, analysts say, not enough to prevent the group from re-emerging intact — and possibly more radicalized.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas supporters parading with empty coffins in a symbolic funeral for Ismail Haniyeh, a top Hamas leader, on Friday in Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: War Shatters Dating Scene for Women in Ukraine
item.description: While the pursuit of love might seem secondary to dealing with the horrors and privations of the war, many Ukrainians say they need romantic relationships to help them cope.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut, Daria Mitiuk and Oksana Parafeniuk
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman smokes hookah at the Forsage night club in Kyiv, last month.

item.title: As Ukraine Collects Medals in Paris, Its Sports Pipeline Is in Tatters
item.description: Facilities have been battered. Coaches are in short supply. Children have moved abroad. Ukraine faces a long hard road toward rebuilding its athletic programs.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman, Oleksandr Chubko and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: Ganna Gatsko practicing with a javelin in June at Spartak Stadium in Brovary, Ukraine.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ava Pellor for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. stock market saw its biggest daily decline in nearly two years.

item.title: Long Battle for a Ruined City Takes a Desperate Turn
item.description: Ukrainian troops are engaged in a harsh struggle for Toretsk, a strategic city in eastern Ukraine that has been under relentless assault by Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: An artillery unit of Ukraine’s 95th Separate Air Assault Brigade firing a howitzer last month at Russian troops trying to capture Toretsk, in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: To Save His Shrinking City, a Mayor Turns to Koreans Uprooted by Stalin
item.description: Like many South Korean cities, Jecheon is being eroded by rapid aging and rock-bottom birthrates. Can ethnic Korean migrants from Central Asia turn it around?
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jecheon, like many other small cities in South Korea, is being eroded by rapid aging and low birthrates.

item.title: As Israel Braces for Iran’s Retaliation, Diplomats Scramble
item.description: President Biden convened his national security team and spoke with King Abdullah II of Jordan, and foreign ministers from Islamic countries plan to gather in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Hamas and Hezbollah drove through the streets of Saida, Lebanon, following tributes for the slain Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and the Hezbollah commander Fuad Shukr, on Aug. 2.

item.title: U.S. Troops in Iraq Are Wounded in Rocket Attack on Air Base
item.description: The attack late Monday resembled previous ones carried out by Iraqi armed groups, backed by Iran, which have targeted the base repeatedly over the past nine months.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Ain al Asad Air Base in western Iraq, which houses U.S. troops, was attacked late Monday, injuring several Americans.

item.title: U.N. Fires Nine Aid Workers Accused of Taking Part in Oct. 7 Attack, but Clears 10 Others
item.description: Israel accused 19 UNRWA employees of playing a role in the Hamas-led raids that set off the war. Investigators cleared 10 for lack of evidence, but said the other nine “may have been involved.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Ephrat Livni
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians receiving food aid at the UNRWA center in Rafah, Gaza, in January.

item.title: Violent U.K. Riots Pose Challenge to Keir Starmer’s New Government
item.description: The new Labour government’s strong law-and-order approach to the violence has mostly spared it from criticism, even from the Conservatives, who only recently left power. But challenges remain.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer held an emergency meeting last week to discuss anti-immigrant riots following a stabbing attack that was wrongly attributed to a migrant.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Global Markets Fell
item.description: Plus, LeBron James at the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: On the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

item.title: Mexican Reporter Gunned Down, Even With a Security Detail at His Side
item.description: Alejandro Martínez had received so many threats that the Mexican government appointed him protection. On Sunday, he was shot and killed and his bodyguards wounded.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Police officers outside the hospital where the journalist Alejandro Martínez was taken after being shot, in Celaya, Mexico.

item.title: Sheikh Hasina Thought Her Grip on Bangladesh Was Unbreakable
item.description: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, who once brought democratic hope to Bangladesh, turned increasingly autocratic and met her downfall in a crackdown on protesters.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheikh Hasina, who grew more authoritarian as prime minister over the years, fled into exile to India after widespread protests.

item.title: Facing Mass Protests, Bangladesh Leader Quits, Setting Up Power Struggle
item.description: Demonstrators defied a curfew, expecting another in a series of bloody crackdowns, but instead Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina fled.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat, Shayeza Walid and Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: K M Asad/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters stormed the official residence of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina as she fled the country, in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Monday.

item.title: Boxing Officials Offer Little Clarity on Olympic Eligibility Dispute
item.description: Two Olympians whose eligibility to compete as women at the Paris Games has come under scrutiny will fight for medals on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The head of the International Boxing Association, Umar Kremlev, on video screen, claimed blood tests had proved two athletes in the women’s boxing competition were men but provided no evidence.

item.title: Bangladesh Protesters Swarm Sheikh Hasina’s Residence After Prime Minister Flees
item.description: Looters made off with furniture, bedding and potted plants.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson

item.title: How Did Simone Biles Become the G.O.A.T.?
item.description: She sealed her legacy with four medals at the Paris Games. She created it by being herself and going at her own pace.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur

item.title: Why Is Iran Expected to Attack Israel? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Iran has vowed to retaliate for the killing of a senior Hamas leader in Tehran last week in an attack for which it has blamed Israel.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iranians gathered in Tehran on Wednesday after the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, a top Hamas leader.

item.title: He Was Freed From a Brutal Russian Jail. Here’s Why He Wanted to Stay.
item.description: The dissident Ilya Yashin calls his release in a prisoner swap last week an ‘illegal expulsion’ by Russia that damages his ability to be heard at home.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The Russian dissident Ilya Yashin at a news conference in Germany after his release last week. People in Russia “hear you much better when you’re there,” he said later.

item.title: Pentagon Hands Over Last Base in Niger as Extremism Spreads in the Sahel
item.description: Relations between the two countries soured after a coup last year. Now the United States is scrambling to find new security partners.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Just under 400 American troops withdrew from a base in Niamey, Niger’s capital, earlier this year.

item.title: Biles’s Small Slip Stalls Medal Run in Paris Olympics
item.description: Four of the eight gymnasts fell off the beam, including Simone Biles and Sunisa Lee, the other American in the event. Alice D’Amato of Italy won the gold medal.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Simone Biles and several other competitors fell off the beam during the final on Monday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s search for a running mate.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris is expected to announce her running mate on Monday.

item.title: How the 9/11 Plea Deal Came Undone
item.description: A case that had mostly drifted from public consciousness in 12 years of proceedings is back in the spotlight and no closer to trial.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III reversed the plea deal agreement made by a senior Defense Department official whom he had appointed.

item.title: Monday Briefing: A Tense Wait in Israel
item.description: Plus, philanthropy with a dark twist.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran last week after Ismail Haniyeh was assassinated in Iran.

item.title: A weekend ride through Paris. Prizes for the first three finishers.
item.description: The Olympic road cycling events, open for all to watch, end in a sprint to the finish.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das, James Hill and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Israeli Strike on Gaza Shelter Kills at Least 30
item.description: An Israeli airstrike in Gaza City killed at least 30 people, according to a Palestinian emergency agency and local media outlets. Israel said it targeted Hamas “command and control centers.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Iyad Abuheweila and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: In a still image taken from a video, Palestinians carried a person at the site of an Israeli strike on Sunday on a school sheltering displaced people in Gaza City.

item.title: Behind the Biggest Prisoner Swap Since the Cold War
item.description: The recent prisoner exchange between Russia and the U.S. — the biggest and most complex since the Cold War — was a diplomatic chess game that required patience and creativity. Mark Mazzetti, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Laura Salaberry, Christina Shaman and James Surdam

item.title: Ukraine Has Received F-16 Fighter Jets, Zelensky Says
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky did not say whether the jets had already flown combat missions. A shortage of trained pilots and a limited number of jets will constrain their immediate impact.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky on Sunday announcing the arrival of F-16 jets in Ukraine.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel Was Already in a ‘War Against Iran’s Evil Axis’
item.description: A number of international airlines have suspended flights to and from Israel pending expected retaliation against the country by Iran and its Lebanese proxy, Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

item.title: UK Police Brace for Unrest After Southport Stabbing
item.description: Protests escalated over the weekend in towns and cities in England and Northern Ireland, with dozens arrested and more demonstrations unfolding on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins and Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Danny Lawson/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters confronting police officers on Sunday at a hotel in Rotherham, England, that has housed asylum seekers.

item.title: At Least 70 Dead as Bangladesh Protests Grow; Curfew Is Reinstated
item.description: Expanded student protests this weekend, after more than 200 people were killed in a government crackdown in July, have plunged the country into a particularly dangerous phase.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Abu Sufian Jewel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A garment store burning on Sunday during protests in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: Palomar Observatory Bids Farwell to its Cosmic Restaurant
item.description: Palomar Observatory bids farewell to a tradition of napkin rings, cowbells and astronomical table conversation.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: The 200-inch Hale Telescope of the Palomar Observatory, which went into operation in 1948, was the biggest and most important telescope on Earth for half a century.

item.title: At Least 4 Dead and Dozens Missing After Landslide and Flood in China
item.description: Hundreds of people were forced to leave their homes in a mountainous part of Sichuan Province. An expressway bridge collapsed amid heavy rains.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and John Liu
item.media:description: The aftermath of earlier flooding last month that hit another part of Sichuan not far from Kangding, in Ya’an.

item.title: Two are dead after a stabbing attack near Tel Aviv.
item.description: Officials called the Sunday morning attack “complex and difficult,” with the victims in separate but nearby locations. The suspected attacker also died.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Emergency responders at the scene of a stabbing in Holon, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: China’s Olympic Swimming’s Haul: More Medals, More Questions
item.description: A meet overshadowed by questions about doping produced more medals, but fewer golds, than China’s swimmers won at the Tokyo Games.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Vrentas
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wang Shun of China, right, finished behind Léon Marchand of France in the 200 individual medley.

item.title: Hezbollah and Israel Exchange Limited Fire Over the Border
item.description: The attack from Lebanon did not appear to be the major retaliation that Hezbollah has threatened in the wake of the Israeli assassination of a senior commander.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the site of an Israeli strike on the southern Lebanese village of Taybeh on Sunday.

item.title: What Is Paris Like During the Olympics?
item.description: There are people walking around the world’s fashion capital with fluffy cockerels on their heads. This is not normal.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Enthusiasm was high at Stade de France throughout the French men’s rugby team’s run to the gold medal.

item.title: Takeaways From Our Investigation Into Banned A.I. Chips in China
item.description: The Times found an active trade in Nvidia chips in China despite U.S. national security restrictions, as well as unreported incidents of how the technology had been used to further defense research.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: The SEG electronics market in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: With Smugglers and Front Companies, China Is Skirting American A.I. Bans
item.description: The U.S. is trying to stop China from getting Nvidia microchips to advance its military. The private sector is fighting back.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Claire Fu
item.media:description: The bustling SEG electronics market in Shenzhen, China, where customers can buy everything from drones to robotic waiters.

item.title: St. Lucia and Dominica Win First-Ever Olympic Medals
item.description: Gold medals in track and field brought St. Lucia and Dominica into an exclusive club of nations. But for 66 other countries and territories, the wait for an Olympic medal goes on, and on, and on.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Jeré Longman
item.media:description: Julien Alfred’s gold medal in the women’s 100 meters on Saturday was her country’s first Olympic medal.

item.title: St. Lucia gets its first gold medal, thanks to the world’s fastest woman.
item.description: Julien Alfred beat Sha’Carri Richardson of the United States by 15-hundredths of a second to win St. Lucia’s first Olympic medal.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel, Talya Minsberg, Chang W. Lee, Gabriela Bhaskar and Daniel Berehulak

item.title: What Do Athletes Do Between High Jumps at the Olympics?
item.description: The high jump often presents competitors with an abundance of down time. Two rivals fill it in very different ways.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Yaroslava Mahuchikh of Ukraine climbs into a sleeping bag between jumps.

item.title: Killing of Hamas Leader Fuels More Tension Between Biden and Netanyahu
item.description: President Biden has expressed concern that the circumstances of the assassination have thrown cease-fire talks into doubt, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel rejects that idea, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has clashed with President Biden over Israel’s prosecution of the war in Gaza.

item.title: Boxer Imane Khelif Clinches Medal Amid Olympic Eligibility Fight
item.description: Imane Khelif advanced to the semifinals, ensuring she will leave the Paris Games with at least a bronze medal.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan
item.media:description: Imane Khelif of Algeria defeated Anna Luca Hamori of Hungary via unanimous decision on Saturday.

item.title: Violent Protests Grip U.K. in Wake of Knife Attack at Dance Class
item.description: Far-right groups and anti-immigration protesters have taken to the streets after a mass stabbing in the town of Southport was followed by a wave of disinformation about the identity of the attacker.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Anti-immigrant protesters confront the police in Nottingham, England, on Saturday.

item.title: Simone Biles’s gold-medal-winning Yurchenko double pike, frame by frame.
item.description: Biles won her second Olympic vault title — eight years after her first in Rio — with her signature Yurchenko double pike and then a vault called a Cheng.
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Olympic Men’s 100: Is It Still a Can’t Miss Moment?
item.description: Lacking star power and tense rivalries, the event was not even the most anticipated 100-meter race at the Paris Games.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:description: Noah Lyles of the United States is the reigning world champion in the 100.

item.title: Inside the Russian Prisoner Swap: Long Johns, Forensics and a Bound Killer
item.description: The complex choreography caught some prisoners being freed in their robes and slippers, unaware of their fates, and required forensic experts to make positive identifications.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Mark Mazzetti
item.media:description: A Russian government plane and private jets sitting on the tarmac at the Esenboga Airport in Ankara on Thursday.
